Article.ArticleTitle: Lab- and pilot-scale wet scrubber study on the redox-mediated simultaneous removal of NO<sub>x</sub> and SO<sub>2</sub> using a CaCO<sub>3</sub>-based slurry with KI as a redox catalyst.

AbstractText: This study presents a novel approach that integrates ozone-driven chemical oxidation to convert NO into soluble NO<sub>2</sub>, followed by the simultaneous absorption of NO<sub>2</sub> and SO<sub>2</sub> into a CaCO<sub>3</sub>-based slurry using the redox catalyst potassium iodide (KI). Using cyclic voltammetry, we demonstrate the redox properties of the I<sub>2</sub>/2I<sup>-</sup> couple, which facilitates NO<sub>2</sub> reduction into soluble NO<sub>2</sub><sup>-</sup> and catalyst regeneration through sulfite (SO<sub>3</sub><sup>2-</sup>)-driven reduction, thus establishing a closed catalytic cycle within the components of flue gas. In lab-scale wet-scrubbing tests, we explore the effect of various operational parameters (i.e., KI concentration, pH, and SO<sub>2</sub> concentration), with a 15 h stability test demonstrating >60% NO<sub>x</sub> and >99% SO<sub>2</sub> removal efficiency when the pH is controlled between 7.5 and 8.5. A successful pilot-scale implementation conducted at an inlet flow rate of 1000 m<sup>3</sup> h<sup>-1</sup> further confirmed the reproducibility of the proposed redox-catalytic cycle. Our study offers a cost-effective, sustainable, and scalable solution for effectively mitigating NO<sub>x</sub> and SO<sub>2</sub> emissions at low temperatures.
